facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 233 of 1954 was filed in the Supreme Court.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated August 22, 1950 of Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 80 of 1946.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated August 22, 1950, of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 80 of 1946 from original decree,

facts.text: Original decree from judgment dated October 19, 1945 of Civil Judge Senior Division Dharwar in Special Suit No. 64 of 1943.

anchor.surface_text: from original decree, arising out of the judgment and decree dated October 19, 1945, of the Court of Civil Judge, Senior Division,

facts.text: M. B. Jakati, defendant No. 1, was Managing Director of Dharwar Urban Co-operative Bank Limited which went into liquidation.

anchor.surface_text: The facts of the case lie in a narrow companypass. M. B. Jakati, defendant No. 1, was the Managing Director of Dharwar Urban Co-operative Bank Limited which went into liquidation,

facts.text: Defendant No. 1 received yearly remuneration of Rs. 1,000 as Managing Director.

anchor.surface_text: and in that capacity he was receiving a yearly remuneration of Rs. 1,000.

facts.text: Payment order for Rs. 15,100 made by Deputy Registrar of Co-operative Societies against defendant No. 1 on April 21, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of certain proceedings taken against defendant No. 1, M. B. Jakati, by the liquidator of the Bank, a payment order for Rs. 15,100 was made by the Deputy Registrar of Co-operative Societies on April 21, 1942.

facts.text: Bungalow belonging to M. B. Jakati attached by Collector under Bombay Land Revenue Code on July 27, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: In execution of this payment order a bungalow belonging to M. B. Jakati, defendant No. 1, was attached by the Collector under the Bombay Land Revenue Code on July 27, 1942.

facts.text: Notice for sale issued on November 24, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: Notice for sale was issued on November 24, 1942, and the proclamation on December 24, 1942.

facts.text: Proclamation on December 24, 1942. Sale fixed for February 2, 1943.

anchor.surface_text: Notice for sale was issued on November 24, 1942, and the proclamation on December 24, 1942. The sale was fixed for February 2, 1943.

facts.text: Defendant No. 1 applied for postponing the sale on January 16, 1943, which was rejected.

anchor.surface_text: On January 16, 1943, B. Jakati defendant No. 1 applied for postponing the sale which was rejected.

facts.text: Auction sale held on February 2, 1943, confirmed on June 23, 1943. Purchaser S. N. Borkar, defendant No. 7, respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: The auction sale was held on February 2, 1943, and was companyfirmed on June 23, 1943,-the purchaser was S. N. Borkar, defendant No. 7, number respondent No. 1.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 sold the property to defendants 8 to 10 (respondents 2 to 4) on February 10, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: On February 10, 1944, respondent No. 1 sold the property to defendants 8 to 10 who are respondents 2 to 4.

facts.text: Krishnaji, son of defendant No. 1, brought suit for partition on January 15, 1943.

anchor.surface_text: On January 15, 1943, Krishnaji a son of defendant No. 1 brought a suit for partition of the joint family property

facts.text: Plaintiff alleged purchase by respondent No. 1 not binding on joint family due to illegal and immoral acts of defendant No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: and possession of his separate share alleging inter alia that the purchase by respondent No. 1 of the bungalow was number binding on the joint family as it was number liable to be sold for the illegal and immoral acts

facts.text: Plaintiff claimed 1/4 share of the property.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff claimed 1/4 share of the property and also alleged that he was number on good terms with his father

facts.text: Appellant No. 1 filed written statement on January 12, 1944 supporting partition and claiming own share.

anchor.surface_text: On January 12, 1944, appellant No. 1 filed his written statement supporting the claim for partition and claiming his own share.

facts.text: Defendant No. 2 (mother) supported plaintiff's claim; after Krishnaji's death, claimed his share as heir.

anchor.surface_text: Defendant No. 2, number appellant No. 2, the mother, also supported the plaintiffs claim and on the death of Krishnaji, she claimed his i share as his heir.

facts.text: Shriniwas substituted as plaintiff on June 28, 1944 after Krishnaji's death.

anchor.surface_text: After the death of the original plaintiff Krishnaji, Shriniwas appellant No. 1 was substituted as plaintiff on June 28, 1944.

facts.text: Trial Court held suit not collusive, debt avyavaharika, declared 1/3 shares each to appellant 1, def1, appellant 2.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Civil Judge, held that the suit was companylusive that the liability which defendant No. 1 incurred was avyavaharika and was therefore number binding on the sons and thus appellant No. 1 would have 1/3 share

facts.text: High Court held debt not avyavaharika, whole estate including sons' share sold under s.155 Bombay Land Revenue Code.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal the High Court held that the debt was number avyavaharika as there was numberevidence to support the finding of the trial Court,... the whole estate including the share of the sons was sold

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeal on September 24, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. September 24. The judgment of Imam and Kapur JJ. was delivered by Kapur J.

issues.text: whether the debt of the father was avyavaharika

anchor.surface_text: The first question for decision is whether the debt of the father was avyavaharika. This term has been variously translated as being that which is not lawful or what is not just or what is not admissible under the law or under normal conditions. Colebrooke translated it as a debt for a cause repugnant to good morals .

issues.text: effect of severance of status brought about by the filing of the suit on January 15, 1943

anchor.surface_text: effect of severance of status brought about by the filing of the suit on January 15, 1943, made the basis of the argument that only the share of the father could be seized in execution of the payment order made against him. This would necessitate an examination into the rights and liabilities of Hindu sons in a Mitakshara coparcenary family where the father is the karta.

issues.text: what interest passed to the auction purchaser on a sale under s. 155 of the Bombay Land Revenue Code

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the question as to what interest passed to the auction purchaser on a sale under s. 155 of the Bombay Land Revenue Code, it held that the whole estate including the share of the sons was sold in execution of the payment order and therefore qua that property the sons had nointerest left.

issues.text: how the liability of the sons is to be enforced

anchor.surface_text: The question then arises how the liability of the sons is to be enforced. Another principle of Hindu law is that in a coparcenary family the decree obtained against the father is binding on the sons as they would be deemed to have been represented by the father in the suit

issues.text: what did the court intend to sell and did sell and what did the auction purchaser purport to buy and did buy and what did he pay for

anchor.surface_text: The question which assumes importance in an auction sale of this kind therefore is what did the court intend to sell and did sell and what did the auction purchaser purport to buy and did buy and what did he pay for. One track of decision of which Shambu Nath Pandey v. Golab Singh is an instance, shows when the fathers share alone passes.

arguments.claim: The debt incurred by defendant No. 1 was avyavaharika (illegal or immoral) due to misfeasance and negligence, hence not binding on the joint family or sons.

arguments.court_reasoning: Pious obligation continues post-partition; creditor can sell whole erstwhile coparcenary property per Panna Lal, Sidheshwar Mukherji.

No need to implead sons post-partition in execution; pious obligation suffices.

anchor.surface_text: where after attachment and a proper notice of sale the whole estate including the sons share, which was attached, is sold and the purchaser buys it intending it to be the whole coparcenary estate

holdings.text: The debt was therefore binding on the sons.

anchor.surface_text: The debt was therefore binding on the sons. The effect of severance of status brought aboutthe filing of the suit on January 25, 1943, made the basis of the argument that only the share of the father could be seized in execution of the payment order made against him. This would necessitate an examination into the rights and liabilities of Hindu sons in a Mitakshara coparcenary family where the father is the karta.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Payment order inadmissible under s.43 Evidence Act to prove nature of debt; negligence as managing director not repugnant to good morals per Colebrooke translation and Privy Council precedents (Hem Raj, Toshanpal Singh).

holdings.text: the liability of the sons to discharge the debts of the father which are not tainted with immorality or illegality is based on the pious obligation of the sons which continues to exist in the lifetime and after the death of the father and which does not come to an end as a result of partition of the joint family property. All that results from partition is that the right of the father to make an alienation comes to an end.

anchor.surface_text: We hold therefore 1 that the liability of the sons to discharge the debts of the father which are not tainted with immorality or illegality is based on the pious obligation of the sons which continues to exist in the lifetime and after the death of the father and which does not come to an end as a result of partition of the joint family property.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pious obligation overrides coparcenary rights and continues post-partition per settled law and precedents (Panna Lal, Sidheshwar Mukherji, Masit Ullah); partition ends father's alienation power but not creditor's enforcement right.

holdings.text: Where the right, title and interest of a judgment-debtor are set up for sale as to what passes to the auction-purchaser is a question of fact in each case dependent upon what was the estate put up for sale, what the Court intended to sell and what the purchaser intended to buy and did buy and what he paid for.

anchor.surface_text: 2 Where the right, title and interest of a judgment-debtor are set up for sale as to what passes to the auction-purchaser is a question of fact in each case dependent upon what was the estate put up for sale, what the Court intended to sell and what the purchaser intended to buy and did buy and what he paid for.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Factual inquiry into intention based on documents (proclamation, confirmation, certificate); distinguished cases like Shambu Nath (father's share only) vs Meenakshi Naidu (whole estate).

holdings.text: There is little doubt therefore that what was put up for auction sale was the whole bungalow and what the auction-purchaser purported to buy and paid for was also the whole bungalow and not any fractional share in it.

anchor.surface_text: There is little doubt therefore that what was put up for auction sale was the whole bungalow and what the auction-purchaser purported to buy and paid for was also the whole bungalow and not any fractional share in it. It is a case where not only was the payment order passed before the partition but the attachment was made and the sale proclamation was issued before the suit for partition was filed and the sale took place of the whole property without any protest or challenge by the sons and without any notice to the Collector or the judgment-creditor of the filing of the suit for partition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proclamation described whole plot No.36-D valued Rs.13,000; confirmation and certificate for whole bungalow; attachment and proclamation pre-partition suit.

holdings.text: The words right, title and interest occurring in s. 155 of the Bombay Land Revenue Code have the same connotation as they had in the corresponding words used in the Code of Civil Procedure existing at the time the Bombay Land Revenue Code was enacted.

anchor.surface_text: 3 The words right, title and interest occurring in s. 155 of the Bombay Land Revenue Code have the same connotation as they had in the corresponding words used in the Code of Civil Procedure existing at the time the Bombay Land Revenue Code was enacted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Similar language in BLRC s155 and contemporaneous CPC; effect factual per precedents (Rai Babu Mahabir Prasad, Meenakshi Naidu); BLRC sale same effect as Civil Court sale.

holdings.text: In execution proceedings it is not necessary to implead the sons or to bring another suit if severance of status takes place pending the execution proceedings because the pious duty of the sons continues and consequently there is merely a difference in the mode of enjoyment of the property.

anchor.surface_text: 4 In execution proceedings it is not necessary to implead the sons or to bring another suit if severance of status takes place pending the execution proceedings because the pious duty of the sons continues and consequently there is merely a difference in the mode of enjoyment of the property.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Father represents sons in coparcenary; post-partition change in enjoyment mode per CPC s64 analogy; no need post-attachment if whole sold; distinguished Ganpatrao, Kameshwaramma on facts.

holdings.text: The liability of a father, who is a managing director and who draws a salary or a remuneration, incurred as a result of negligence in the discharge of his duties is not an avyavaharika debt as it cannot be termed as repugnant to good morals.

anchor.surface_text: 5 The liability of a father, who is a managing director and who draws a salary or a remuneration, incurred as a result of negligence in the discharge of his duties is not an avyavaharika debt as it cannot be termed as repugnant to good morals.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Modern banking context; vigilance expected but negligence not immoral per Colebrooke; remuneration indicates legitimate capacity.

anchor.surface_text: The debt was therefore binding on the sons. The effect of severance of status brought aboutthe filing of the suit on January 25, 1943, made the basis of the argument that only the share of the father could be seized in execution of the payment order made against him. This would necessitate an examination into the rights and liabilities of Hindu sons in a Mitakshara coparcenary family where the father is the karta.
In the result the appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: We hold therefore 1 that the liability of the sons to discharge the debts of the father which are not tainted with immorality or illegality is based on the pious obligation of the sons which continues to exist in the lifetime and after the death of the father and which does not come to an end as a result of partition of the joint family property.
In the result the appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: 2 Where the right, title and interest of a judgment-debtor are set up for sale as to what passes to the auction-purchaser is a question of fact in each case dependent upon what was the estate put up for sale, what the Court intended to sell and what the purchaser intended to buy and did buy and what he paid for.
In the result the appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: There is little doubt therefore that what was put up for auction sale was the whole bungalow and what the auction-purchaser purported to buy and paid for was also the whole bungalow and not any fractional share in it. It is a case where not only was the payment order passed before the partition but the attachment was made and the sale proclamation was issued before the suit for partition was filed and the sale took place of the whole property without any protest or challenge by the sons and without any notice to the Collector or the judgment-creditor of the filing of the suit for partition.

anchor.surface_text: 3 The words right, title and interest occurring in s. 155 of the Bombay Land Revenue Code have the same connotation as they had in the corresponding words used in the Code of Civil Procedure existing at the time the Bombay Land Revenue Code was enacted.

anchor.surface_text: 4 In execution proceedings it is not necessary to implead the sons or to bring another suit if severance of status takes place pending the execution proceedings because the pious duty of the sons continues and consequently there is merely a difference in the mode of enjoyment of the property.
In the result the appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.
